public interface Node<T> {
	protected void process(T value) {

	// class

	public static In<T> extends Node<T> {
		public void connectFrom(Node.Out<? super T> node);
	}

	public static Out<T> extends Node<T> {
		public void connectTo(Node.In<? extends T> node);
	}
}

Now, create some delegator classes that extend and use Node as a 
delegate for passing various types and subtypes of data.

public interface Type {}
public interface SubType extends Type {}

public interface Delegator {
	public Node<Type> getNodeIn();
	public Node<Type> getNodeOut();
}

public interface SubDeleg {
	public Node<SubType> getNodeIn();
	public Node<SubType> getNodeOut();
}

How do you test to make sure that what you think should happen actually 
happens at compile time?  Don't forget that JUnit is about regression 
testing.  If you make some change in the type hierarchies or 
implementations, how do you make sure you haven't broken the 
compile-time enforcement of what should and should not be allowed...


DelegatorA.getNodeOut().connectTo(DelegatorB.getNodeIn()); // no error
DelegatorA.getNodeIn().connectTo(DelegatorB.getNodeOut()); // error
DelegatorA.getNodeOut().connectFrom(DelegatorB.getNodeIn()); // error
DelegatorA.getNodeIn().connectFrom(DelegatorB.getNodeOut()); // no error

DelegatorA.getNodeOut().connectTo(DelegatorB.getNodeIn()); // no error
DelegatorA.getNodeIn().connectTo(SubDelegB.getNodeOut()); // error
SubDelegA.getNodeOut().connectTo(DelegatorB.getNodeIn()); // no error
SubDelegA.getNodeIn().connectTo(SubDelegB.getNodeOut()); // no error

etc, etc, etc....

To make the argument even more compelling, add a few more generic 
methods to Node.In and Node.Out.  Now create a Node.InOut by extending 
Node.In and Node.Out, and test for combinations of In-InOut, Out-InOut, 
InOut-In, etc, etc.

As a client I can use one such method and can readily see if there is a 
compile error.  However, as a developer I'd like to be able to test for 
all the key combinations and permutations, which can only be done 
statically, at compile time.

So, is there any way for JUnit to include an assertion for a compile 
time error?  Earlier attempts on my part, and suggestions by others, 
have been unsuccessful.  Is this something that is currently impossible 
in Java?

--jon	

> Message: 7 Date: Tue May 30, 2006 10:57 am (PDT) From: "J. B.
> Rainsberger" jbrains@... Subject: Re: testing for compile
> errors Jon Barrilleaux wrote:
> 
>>> A while back I posted a question/suggestion about being able to
>>> test for compile-time erros.  Such testing is especially
>>> important in the presence of java generics -- you want to be sure
>>> that some data types, such as in method parameters, compile
>>> correctly, but others result in a compile error.  Testing these
>>> cases by hand defeats the whole purpose of unit testing.
>>> 
>>> Is there any way to test for a compile time error in a JUnit
>>> test?  Is this something that would be impossible to add?
> 
> 
> I am not a Java 5 programmer, and do not play one on TV, but I'd love
> to see an example of this where compiling or not compiling isn't
> blaringly obvious to any competent person reading the code. -- J. B.
